awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Computational Modeling for Individual and Organizational Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description of the Significance and Importance

Mathematics is the language of science, yet in the social sciences computational representations of the processes hypothesized to explain phenomena are rare. A primary reason for this is a lack of understanding of the value of formal, computational approaches and a lack of training in computational modeling strategies. This lack of appreciation and training is particularly true at the intersection of psychology and organizational science, which includes the disciplines of industrial-organizational psychology and organizational behavior. The workshop at the Ohio University brings together an international group of scholars from several sub-disciplines of psychology and organizational science to highlight the value and training a new set of scholars in computational modeling methodology. 

Technical Description 

The intellectual merit of the project arises from a series of presentations by computational modelers of difference types that will focus on the value of computational modeling for addressing specific phenomena and for facilitating the construction of a cumulative science focused on understanding human behavior at work. That is, computational modeling provides researchers with the means to explore dynamic psychological and contextual concepts mathematically and with simulations, including information regarding what study designs can be used to investigate the causal theories properly. Moreover, quantitative modeling techniques provide a vehicle for integrating levels of theory ranging from neurological to macro processes (e.g., economic activity). The broader impact of this project will be achieved via training of a cadre of new computational modelers and the publication of an edited collection of the papers presented by the established modelers and newly trained modelers. That is, as part of the training element of the workshop the trainees will develop and evaluate new computational models of specific phenomena. The best of these models will be submitted to journals for special issue consideration on computational modeling.

por.por_cntn:
This workshop grant supported a two and half day conference/workshop on computational modeling as well as a follow-up webinar where computational models were presented and discussed. Computational modeling is a formal (i.e., mathematical) method of presenting theory that is underutilized in applied psychology and organizational science. The computational modeling approach is of considerable intellectual merit because formalization (i.e., mathematical representation) of theory is the hallmark of a mature science. The workshop brought together experts who computationally model phenomena of interest to psychologists and management researchers and allowed individual from different perspectives to take stock of the work being conducted in other areas. In terms of broader impact, a primary objective of the workshop was to expand the number of computational modelers in organizational science. To accomplish this the workshop brought together both experts in computational modeling and novice modelers interested in learning the techniques (see Appendix A). Specifically, eight expects in computational modeling presented their views of computational modeling’s role in supporting scientific endeavors (see Schedule, Appendix B). Time was provided for informal interactions among the expert and novice participants throughout this first day of the conference. On the second day, two workshops were provided on two prominent computational modeling approaches: system dynamics and agent-based modeling. To participate in these workshops the novice modelers submitted a proposed model to be developed during the workshop. Based on the nature of the model each individual wished to develop, the individual was assigned to the appropriate workshop. Experts were welcome to join these workshops based on desire, and some did. In the last half day of the conference/workshop the novices worked on their specific models with the help of the workshop leaders. Eleven models were initiated or further developed during this period. Finally, two and a half months later a webinar was conducted where the novice modelers presented the results of the models they had been working on and sought additional advice regarding how to proceed to creating a publishable product.

A compendium of the presentations, models, and reference materials were collected for a Dropbox folder accessible to the workshop participants. For several of the novice modelers the models they developed were the basis of dissertations (e.g. Morgan Bulger; Yihao Liu), whereas for others (e.g., Jay Hardy; Kristen Sotak) they were the basis of conference presentations (AOM) and/or journal articles (e.g., Journal of Leadership Quarterly). Likewise, several of the experts (Justin Weinhardt, James Grand, Corrine Coen, Xiaofei Li & Jeff Vancouver) honed their presentations for a professional conference (SIOP). At this time, we are negotiating an edited book deal on computational modeling with the intent of including several of the models developed in the workshiop. Finalyl, Two of the workshop coordinators (Xiaofei Li & Vancouver) submitted an annotated bibliography on computational modeling in organizational sciences for Oxford Bibliographies in January of this year (2016).
